Asia's Gen Z rises up against entrenched political elites
subhead: Since 2022, young people in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Nepal have led a wave of uprisings to demand radical change, united by a common cause: frustration with politicians' corruption and self-granted privileges.

'Get up or I'll smash you': French police violence mars September 10 and 18 protests
subhead: Testimonies reveal the violence committed during the protests organized by the 'Block Everything' movement and a coalition of unions. Lawyers criticize 'extremely incomplete files' for the arrests conducted and denounce 'preventive police custody.'

title: Madagascar president sacks government over deadly protests
subhead: The UN's human rights chief on Monday condemned  Madagascar's 'violent response' to the protests, at which his office says 'at least 22 people have been killed and more than a hundred injured.'

title: Sarkozy verdict reveals complicated relationship between the French, politicians and judges
subhead: Following the conviction of France's former president, attacks on judges have returned to the political discourse. Yet this court decision is also the result of growing public demand for integrity.

title: Charlie Kirk's memorial through the lens of photographer Stacy Kranitz: 'The first few hours felt like a megachurch service'
subhead: Stacy Kranitz, an American photographer born in 1974, covered the memorial ceremony for the ultraconservative activist on September 21 for Le Monde. She reflects on this spectacular event, which combined politics with religion.

subhead: Tensions with Russia to the East and the United States to the West are testing Europe's model. Sylvain Kahn and Guillaume Lagane examine this shifting landscape and the possible responses.

title: At Musée d'Orsay, John Singer Sargent, an American in Paris
subhead: While revered by major museums internationally, the painter remains little known in France. Focusing on his Paris years, his first exhibition seeks to correct that oversight.

title: Svalbard, the fastest-warming place on Earth
subhead: 'Our planet at +1.5°C' (1/6). The Norwegian archipelago has warmed by 4°C over the past 30 years. Landslides and thawing permafrost threaten the population, whose way of life is highly greenhouse gas-intensive.
